bestBHT.bht: Moses is captivated by a remarkable vision: a burning bush that is not consumed. This sight amazes him as it is a direct manifestation of Jehovah himself. Jesus later uses this event to defend the belief in resurrection and the future life. Moses is struck with admiration and approaches the bush with a mixture of curiosity and fear, desiring to comprehend its significance. The fact that the bush is on fire but remains unconsumed is a marvel that sparks his wonder and curiosity.

Albert Barnes: What particularly attracted his attention was the fact that the bush was not consumed."
Yahweh spake to him from the midst of the bush. He did not see him. He merely heard a voice.
Marvin Vincent: The sight [το οραμα] . Always in the New Testament of a vision. See on Matthew 17:9.
To behold [κατανοησαι] . See on Matthew 7:3. Compare Luke 12:24, Luke 12:27.
John Calvin: He meant to make a manifest distinction between the visions which he showed, and the juggling casts of Satan."
This alone is the true stay of faith, to have God to be the author thereof, that he may undoubtedly declare that it is he that speaketh.

For this cause was the mind of Moses stricken with admiration, and then afterwards he draweth near to consider; after that he is come nearer, the Lord toucheth him with a more lively feeling of his presence, so that he is afraid.
Archibald T. Robertson: Here the angel of Jehovah of verse Acts 7:30 is termed Jehovah himself.
Jesus makes powerful use of these words in his reply to the Sadducees in defence of the doctrine of the resurrection and the future life.
The adjective εντρομος (εν, τρομος from τρεμω, to tremble, to quake) occurs in Plutarch and the LXX.
John Gill: To see a bush on fire was no extraordinary thing; but to see a bush on fire, and yet not consumed by it, which was the case here, was wonderful indeed."
and that an angel of the Lord, or the Lord himself, should appear in it, made it still more amazing
and which struck him with wonder, and excited his curiosity

bhtAttempts.bht: In this verse, the author uses the word sight to describe the vision that Moses sees in the burning bush. This vision, where the bush is on fire but not consumed, is significant because it is a manifestation of Jehovah himself. Jesus later refers to this event in his defense of the doctrine of the resurrection and the future life. Moses is struck with admiration and draws near to consider this miraculous sight, feeling the presence of the Lord and experiencing a sense of fear. The fact that the bush is on fire but not consumed is truly amazing and captures Moses' curiosity.

In this passage, Moses witnesses a remarkable vision: a burning bush that remains unconsumed. This extraordinary sight catches his attention because it is a direct encounter with Jehovah himself. Jesus later uses this event to defend the belief in the resurrection and the afterlife. Moses is in awe and approaches the bush with a combination of admiration and fear, drawn to understand its significance. The fact that the bush is both on fire and unconsumed provides a sense of wonder and raises his curiosity.

Moses witnesses an astonishing sight: a burning bush that remains unharmed. This vision captivates him because it is a direct encounter with Jehovah himself. Jesus later references this event to defend the idea of resurrection and the afterlife. Moses is awestruck and approaches the bush with a mix of admiration and fear, drawn to understand its significance. The fact that the bush is on fire but not consumed fills him with wonder and piques his curiosity.

Moses is struck with admiration and approaches the bush with a mixture of curiosity and fear, desiring to comprehend its significance. The fact that the bush is on fire but remains unconsumed is a marvel that sparks his wonder and curiosity.

Moses witnesses an extraordinary sight: a burning bush that remains unharmed. This vision captivates him because it is a direct encounter with Jehovah himself. Jesus later references this event to defend the concept of resurrection and the afterlife. Moses is filled with awe and approaches the bush with a mix of admiration and fear, drawn to understand its significance. The fact that the bush is on fire but not consumed arouses wonder and curiosity, leaving Moses amazed by this miraculous sight.
